Course Description: This course will introduce basic theoretical models of IO. It will implement applied microeconomics theory and game theory to understand how firms take decisions in various settings. The models include profit maximization when there is market power, advertising, heterogeneity in quality, vertical control, models of entry, accommodation and exit, and many others. The course helps one understand how to set up an objective function for a firm facing different challenges in a complex market structure. It will aid the student in understanding real world scenarios. Finally there will also be a short section on some empirical methods used in IO.

Course Outcomes.CO1: Identifying how to approach a problem in IO in a strategic setting
Course Outcomes.CO2: Determining how to model decision that influence profit, like advertising, quality, collusion etc.
Course Outcomes.CO3: Discussing decisions in monopolies, duopolies, vertical control.
Course Outcomes.CO4: Justifying and explaining what motivates a firm to enter or exit a market.
Course Outcomes.CO5: Identifying and Implementing some basic empirical and applied theory techniques in IO (for 5XX).

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Product Differentiation: Price Competition and Non-Price Competition

Textbook.3XX and 5XX: Belleflamme, Paul, and Martin Peitz. Industrial organization: markets and strategies. Cambridge University Press, 2015.

Resource Material.Textbook (5XX only): Tirole, J., The Theory of Industrial Organization, Eastern Economy Edition.
